For many years administration of the Garo Hills was delayed by the extremely serious malaria which was, and still is, characteristic of the district. Finally, however, in 1867, the district was occupied, permanent headquarters were established at Tura, and peace was rapidly achieved. The American Baptist Missionary Society sent missionaries to the Garo Hills almost immediately after the government was established, and these were followed, in this century, by Catholic missionaries, with the result that today between one-quarter and one-third of the Garos are Christians, the largest number of them Baptist.’ [275] Given the absence of urbanism and literacy among the pre-colonial A’chik, their conflicts with the British can be characterized as occurring on the Urbanism-Literacy frontier.

♠ Wars on steppe frontier ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Wars on agricultural frontier ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

Intensity of warfare[edit]

♠ Annexation ♣ present: 1867-1873 CE; absent: 1874-1956 CE ♥ The British sent punitive campaigns into the hills in order to suppress resistance as well as infighting. Full administrative control was established around 1873. Most authors consider the area 'pacified' for the remainder of the colonial period. ‘During the first few years of the British rule in Assam the district of Garo Hills was treated as a part of the Goalpara district. The whole tract was placed under a Civil Commissioner. This officer took into his hands the collection of rents claimed by the Zaminders from the Garos, and abolished the duties levied by them on the hill produces. For some years a policy of non-interference was followed but without the desired success; so it was decided to appoint an officer-in-charge of the hills and in 1869 a.d. the Garo Hills were formed into a separate district with Tura as its headquarters. It is said in some parts of the district even now that the British administrators had to get away with many of the influential chiefs and other men of the tribe by killing them for, they could not easily bow down to the foreigners. Once this hills area was completely brouht undegr the control of the government, the Garos lived peacefully.’ [276] ‘During the period 1867-71 about 100 major villages of the Garo Hills were brought under control. But even then villages in the interiors again and again caused trouble in administered areas. So, ultimately to bring under administration the entire Garo Hills, British authorities led a three pronged punitive expedition in the year 1872. It was planned that a column would be led by Captain Davis from the northern borders, the second column would be led by Mr. Daly from the southern borders, and the third column was to be led by Capt. Williamson himself from the district headquarters. All these three columns were to meet in the Rongrenggiri area, in the central region of the district, which was inhabited by the Matchi, considered to be the most obstinate sub-tribe. All the three columns could reach Rongrenggiri as planned, and none got any remarkable resistance on the way. But at Rongrenggiri the Garo fought with them very valiently; but as they had no firearms, British forces easily defeated them. After these expeditions the Garo in all areas submitted to British authorities and the entire district came under their administrative control.’ [277] ‘Since the annexation of the Garo Hills by the British Government, a body of men called laskars has been formed, who act as a kind of rural police and also as honorary magistrates. They are empowered to deal with all minor matters and settle unimportant disputes. They do this by calling together meetings of villagers, in which they sit as presidents and give final decisions. Their powers do not exceed those of inflicting fines and awarding compensation to injured parties. This is but an adaptation of the ancient usages of the people, for in former times, the village met in conference to decide any matter in dispute between its members. When in these meetings evidence could not be adduced, recourse was, and is yet had to trial by ordeal.’ [278]

♠ Looting ♣ present: 1867-1873 CE; absent: 1874-1956 CE ♥ ‘Hunting, raiding, beheading and attacking were the way of life for the Garo. In those days, people collected human skulls and decorated the roof of their houses with them. Head hunting was considered an act of chivalry, a symbol of higher status and social distinction. We may speculate that this practice might have originated owing to mutual suspicions, which led to attack and counter-attack. But it is clear that this was not a senseless activity because the institution of slavery was closely associated with it. During the raids the people who were caught were kept as ‘nokkol’ (slaves). These slaves were expected to work in the fields and households of their masters. Keeping slaves was not merely a status symbol but enhanced the economy and position of their masters. Some of the prosperous families had as many as sixty slaves. More slaves meant more prosperity of their owners. As their economic status went up they engaged themselves in trade. They could not tolerate the sight of an outsider anywhere as a result of which a lot of mutual suspicion was generated. They often raided the villages in the neighbourhood, as well as in the plains (Pianazzi Fr. 1934, p. 3).’ [279]

♠ Sack ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Rape ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Deportation ♣ absent ♥ The Garo hills were annexed by the British, but the local population remained. The A’chik did not deport enemy groups, but took heads and raided enemy villages. ‘Ultimately, they were brought under control, and then the government established an administrative headquarters at Tura and appointed a Deputy Commissioner to carry on the administration of the district. Till that time, the Garos were a head hunting tribe. In the records of the district, it is mentioned that from one village alone more than two hundred human skulls were recovered. It was the custom amongst the Garos to preserve the head of the man killed by them as a trophy. More the number of skulls gathered by an individual more honoured was his place in the society. It was considered as an act of valour and won respect and prestige from the members of the society. They not only carried on organised raids on the villages in the neighbouring districts, i.e., the villages in the districts of Mymensingh, now in East Pakistan, and Goalpara in Assam to collect the human heads but also carried on such raids on enemy villages within the districts of Garo Hills. I have mentioned in connection with the death ceremony that they used to consider it necessary to kill a human being on the occasion of the cremation of the dead body. For this purpose, they used to organise raids on the villages in the plains or on an enemy village in the hills to catch hold of a man who may be brought for the purpose of sacrifice, to be performed, near the funeral pyre. The Mimang (spirit of the dead) of this sacrificed man becomes a nokol, i.e., a servant of the Mimang of the dead person and accompanies the latter to the Mimang land at Balpakram. If a Mimang goes there without a nokol or a cow or some good presents, he is to live there as a nokol of the Mimangs who are well off there.’ [280]

♠ Expulsion ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Enslavement ♣ present: 1867-1873 CE; absent: 1874-1956 CE ♥ ‘Hunting, raiding, beheading and attacking were the way of life for the Garo. In those days, people collected human skulls and decorated the roof of their houses with them. Head hunting was considered an act of chivalry, a symbol of higher status and social distinction. We may speculate that this practice might have originated owing to mutual suspicions, which led to attack and counter-attack. But it is clear that this was not a senseless activity because the institution of slavery was closely associated with it. During the raids the people who were caught were kept as ‘nokkol’ (slaves). These slaves were expected to work in the fields and households of their masters. Keeping slaves was not merely a status symbol but enhanced the economy and position of their masters. Some of the prosperous families had as many as sixty slaves. More slaves meant more prosperity of their owners. As their economic status went up they engaged themselves in trade. They could not tolerate the sight of an outsider anywhere as a result of which a lot of mutual suspicion was generated. They often raided the villages in the neighbourhood, as well as in the plains (Pianazzi Fr. 1934, p. 3).’ [281] ‘I have referred to the human sacrifice which was customary in olden times. Another and more merciful form of celebrating this part of the funeral rites was to keep a living slave tied to the leg of the corpse from the day of the decease to the hour of cremation. He or she was then released from further servitude. When a human sacrifice was considered necessary, but a victim could not be found, the bamboo tray with which the flames were fanned was suspended from a long pole close to the place of cremation. This remained hanging until that part of the funeral rites had been performed.’ [282] ‘They visited markets at bordering plains with their produce from the hills like raw cotton, chillies, ginger, wax, rubber, lac and other things to barter for essential items such as salt, dried fish and jewellery of all kinds and most important metal implements and weapons which they needed so desperately. In other words, to generate surplus they needed slaves. To get slaves they had to attack the plains or neighbouring villages. To win and capture slaves they needed to be strong and alert. Obviously in a situation like this economic strength promoted the physical strength.’ [283]

♠ Imprisonment ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Destruction ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Torture ♣ absent ♥ The A’chik initially took heads and mutilated the bodies of enemies, but did not torture them beforehand. ‘After an attack on a village, if the distance was not too great, the victim was sometimes carried home to the raiders’ village, otherwise, only the head was taken. In the former case it was customary to lay the body on a ganchi or funeral pyre, round which the people danced. The body was then decapitated, and the hands and feet were cut off. The latter were then taken to the outskirts of the village, and placed in holes in the ground in which mandal trees ( Erithrina suberosa) were afterwards planted. In some cases, instead of burying the hands, they were fastened to bamboos with the fingers outspread. These bamboos were then stuck into the ground by the side of the path leading to the next village, as if to warn strangers not to approach. The corpse after having been thus mutilated, was burnt, and the skull was hung up in the latrine of the house of the taker of the trophy.’ [284] ‘Since the annexation of the Garo Hills by the British Government, a body of men called laskars has been formed, who act as a kind of rural police and also as honorary magistrates. They are empowered to deal with all minor matters and settle unimportant disputes. They do this by calling together meetings of villagers, in which they sit as presidents and give final decisions. Their powers do not exceed those of inflicting fines and awarding compensation to injured parties. This is but an adaptation of the ancient usages of the people, for in former times, the village met in conference to decide any matter in dispute between its members. When in these meetings evidence could not be adduced, recourse was, and is yet had to trial by ordeal.’ [285]

♠ Mutilation ♣ present: 1867-1873 CE; absent: 1874-1956 CE ♥ ‘Hunting, raiding, beheading and attacking were the way of life for the Garo. In those days, people collected human skulls and decorated the roof of their houses with them. Head hunting was considered an act of chivalry, a symbol of higher status and social distinction. We may speculate that this practice might have originated owing to mutual suspicions, which led to attack and counter-attack. But it is clear that this was not a senseless activity because the institution of slavery was closely associated with it. During the raids the people who were caught were kept as ‘nokkol’ (slaves). These slaves were expected to work in the fields and households of their masters. Keeping slaves was not merely a status symbol but enhanced the economy and position of their masters. Some of the prosperous families had as many as sixty slaves. More slaves meant more prosperity of their owners. As their economic status went up they engaged themselves in trade. They could not tolerate the sight of an outsider anywhere as a result of which a lot of mutual suspicion was generated. They often raided the villages in the neighbourhood, as well as in the plains (Pianazzi Fr. 1934, p. 3).’ [286] ‘This collection of human skulls was once a matter of pride to them. The more the number of skulls the higher was their position and respectibility. Time has changed. It is not possible now to kill men and go unpunished. So they have given up that practice. But now they collect skulls of all the games they can bag. This brings them fame in society and is a subject much spoken of.’ [287] ‘After an attack on a village, if the distance was not too great, the victim was sometimes carried home to the raiders’ village, otherwise, only the head was taken. In the former case it was customary to lay the body on a ganchi or funeral pyre, round which the people danced. The body was then decapitated, and the hands and feet were cut off. The latter were then taken to the outskirts of the village, and placed in holes in the ground in which mandal trees ( Erithrina suberosa) were afterwards planted. In some cases, instead of burying the hands, they were fastened to bamboos with the fingers outspread. These bamboos were then stuck into the ground by the side of the path leading to the next village, as if to warn strangers not to approach. The corpse after having been thus mutilated, was burnt, and the skull was hung up in the latrine of the house of the taker of the trophy.’ [288] ‘Ultimately, they were brought under control, and then the government established an administrative headquarters at Tura and appointed a Deputy Commissioner to carry on the administration of the district. Till that time, the Garos were a head hunting tribe. In the records of the district, it is mentioned that from one village alone more than two hundred human skulls were recovered. It was the custom amongst the Garos to preserve the head of the man killed by them as a trophy. More the number of skulls gathered by an individual more honoured was his place in the society. It was considered as an act of valour and won respect and prestige from the members of the society. They not only carried on organised raids on the villages in the neighbouring districts, i.e., the villages in the districts of Mymensingh, now in East Pakistan, and Goalpara in Assam to collect the human heads but also carried on such raids on enemy villages within the districts of Garo Hills. I have mentioned in connection with the death ceremony that they used to consider it necessary to kill a human being on the occasion of the cremation of the dead body. For this purpose, they used to organise raids on the villages in the plains or on an enemy village in the hills to catch hold of a man who may be brought for the purpose of sacrifice, to be performed, near the funeral pyre. The Mimang (spirit of the dead) of this sacrificed man becomes a nokol, i.e., a servant of the Mimang of the dead person and accompanies the latter to the Mimang land at Balpakram. If a Mimang goes there without a nokol or a cow or some good presents, he is to live there as a nokol of the Mimangs who are well off there.’ [289] ‘It was not until 1876 that the last trace of the head-hunting proclivities of the Garos disappeared. In the resolution on the annual report for that year I find it stated that the Deputy Commissioner was able while in camp at Rongrengiri, to settle a number of blood-feuds, and no less than 200 skulls, the remains of victims killed in former raids, or murdered in various ways, were surrendered and publicly burnt.’ [290]

♠ Targeted massacre ♣ present: 1867-1873 CE; absent: 1874-1956 CE ♥ ‘During the first few years of the British rule in Assam the district of Garo Hills was treated as a part of the Goalpara district. The whole tract was placed under a Civil Commissioner. This officer took into his hands the collection of rents claimed by the Zaminders from the Garos, and abolished the duties levied by them on the hill produces. For some years a policy of non-interference was followed but without the desired success; so it was decided to appoint an officer-in-charge of the hills and in 1869 a.d. the Garo Hills were formed into a separate district with Tura as its headquarters. It is said in some parts of the district even now that the British administrators had to get away with many of the influential chiefs and other men of the tribe by killing them for, they could not easily bow down to the foreigners. Once this hills area was completely brouht undegr the control of the government, the Garos lived peacefully.’ [291]

♠ General massacre ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Extermination ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Ethnocide ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.


Archaeological proxies:

♠ Skeletal evidence of violence ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Mass burials ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Settlement destruction ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

♠ Pictorial evidence of warfare ♣ uncoded ♥ Variable not yet been checked for data or no data yet found in the literature.

List of Wars[edit]

Ritual variables[edit]

♠ RA ♣ Daniel Mullins ♥

♠ Expert ♣ ♥

Note: The below rituals were imported from the Ritual Database. There may be ritual transformations that the ethnographic record does not capture. In particular, rituals associated with head-hunting and warfare may demand more consideration in future coding efforts, given the practice of raiding among the A’chik in pre-colonial times (see also below).
The following general description was extracted from the eHRAF Culture Summary for the A’chik: 'There are two faiths prevalent among the Garos: native and Christian. People who follow the traditional faith are known as Songsarek. Difference in religion has not brought any split in the population. The traditional world of the Garos includes a number of spirits who behave like human beings but have no shape. They are SALJONG, the spirit of sun and fertility; GAERA, the spirit of strength and the thunderbolt; SUSIME, the spirit of wealth. Propitiation for each is followed by the sacrifice of an animal and an offering of beer. A Christian Garo is supposed to avoid such practices. There are also ogres and biting spirits, called MITES.' [292] 'A Garo religious practitioner is known as KAMAL. The word is used to mean 'specialist'; thus a midwife may be a kamal. A kamal has neither special privilege nor prestige from his service to the society.' [293] 'All traditional annual festivals were connected with the different stages of shifting cultivation: AGALMAKA, MAIMUQ, RENACHUGALA, AHAIA, WANGALA, etc. Wangala is considered to be the national festival among the Garos, taking place during October-December. When a member of a family becomes Christian, he refuses to participate in Songsarek festivals.' [294]
The following seasonal festivals were not coded for here, but are found in the ritual database: 'The second festival, Agalmaka, was observed after the swiddens had been fired. The festival began with the nokma sacrificing a cock in his own swidden, after which the head of every household in the village would offer an egg, each in his own field. Although the sacrifice and offerings were accomplished in a single morning, the festival itself lasted for several days. On the first day the nokma sponsored a feast for his villagers. After eating and drinking, the [Page 142] people would make music, dance and sing at the nokma’s house. On the following days people would visit each other’s houses, the arrangements for food, drink, dancing and singing being the responsibility of each individual household.'[295] 'Before seeds were sown in the swiddens, the Garo would observe the festival called Asiroka. On this occasion the nokma sacrificed a cock at a bamboo altar erected somewhere within the village itself. Following this sacrifice, the villagers would slaughter a cow, which they had purchased beforehand. This cow was not sacrificed to propitiate any mite, but simply killed for its flesh, which was distributed among the villagers according to the amount of money they had contributed for its purchase in the first place. After this distribution of meat, the villagers returned home to rest for the remainder of the day. The next day, each household head would sacrifice an animal (ox, pig, goat, or at least a cock, the kind of animal depending upon the household’s economic condition) in his own swidden. After the sacrifice the villagers would feast, dance and sing. But the following day was again set aside as a day of rest. After this the villagers began their planting operations.' [296] 'Around June to July, when the padi was growing in the swiddens, the Garo would observe a festival called Miamua. This festival lasted only a single day and, during it, the nokma would sacrifice a pig in his own swidden and sponsor a feast for all the villagers. After the feast, which took place around noon, the people used to sing and play music. But they were forbidden on this occasion to beat drums. It was said that the beating of drums at this particular time could attract the attention of some malevolent mite, like Bang, Rakashi or Chual, who might then decide to come to the village to enjoy the sound of the drums and subsequently cause damage to the growing padi plants. And, because there were no drums to accompany them, the villagers would not dance on the occasion of Miamua either.' [297] 'Before they harvested their swidden crops, the villagers would observe the festival called Rongchugala. This usually fell in August. On this occasion the nokma would offer the mite a special dish called rongchu, which is rice which has been cooked until dry and crisp. The rongchu was spread out on a banana leaf and kept in the nokma’s house. After the nokma had made this traditional offering, there would be feasting, drinking and music-making. But, for the very same reason as at the Miamua festival, there would be no drumming or dancing on this occasion.'[298] 'After the harvest, in September, the Garo villagers observed the festival called Ahaia. On this occasion each household head would prepare a fish for the mite, the offering being made in the farmer’s own swidden. Then, for several days, there would be much feasting, drinking, dancing and music-making. All the households would exchange visits during the course of the Ahaia festival.'[299]
Prior to the colonial period, the A’chik had a tradition of head-hunting and human sacrifice (see also 'warfare' for reference). According to some sources, there was a connection between mortuary ritual and raiding/human sacrifice in pre-colonial times: ‘Hunting, raiding, beheading and attacking were the way of life for the Garo. In those days, people collected human skulls and decorated the roof of their houses with them. Head hunting was considered an act of chivalry, a symbol of higher status and social distinction. We may speculate that this practice might have originated owing to mutual suspicions, which led to attack and counter-attack. But it is clear that this was not a senseless activity because the institution of slavery was closely associated with it. During the raids the people who were caught were kept as ‘nokkol’ (slaves). These slaves were expected to work in the fields and households of their masters. Keeping slaves was not merely a status symbol but enhanced the economy and position of their masters. Some of the prosperous families had as many as sixty slaves. More slaves meant more prosperity of their owners. As their economic status went up they engaged themselves in trade. They could not tolerate the sight of an outsider anywhere as a result of which a lot of mutual suspicion was generated. They often raided the villages in the neighbourhood, as well as in the plains (Pianazzi Fr. 1934, p. 3).’[300] ‘This collection of human skulls was once a matter of pride to them. The more the number of skulls the higher was their position and respectibility. Time has changed. It is not possible now to kill men and go unpunished. So they have given up that practice. But now they collect skulls of all the games they can bag. This brings them fame in society and is a subject much spoken of.’ [301] ‘After an attack on a village, if the distance was not too great, the victim was sometimes carried home to the raiders’ village, otherwise, only the head was taken. In the former case it was customary to lay the body on a ganchi or funeral pyre, round which the people danced. The body was then decapitated, and the hands and feet were cut off. The latter were then taken to the outskirts of the village, and placed in holes in the ground in which mandal trees ( Erithrina suberosa) were afterwards planted. In some cases, instead of burying the hands, they were fastened to bamboos with the fingers outspread. These bamboos were then stuck into the ground by the side of the path leading to the next village, as if to warn strangers not to approach. The corpse after having been thus mutilated, was burnt, and the skull was hung up in the latrine of the house of the taker of the trophy.’ [302] ‘Ultimately, they were brought under control, and then the government established an administrative headquarters at Tura and appointed a Deputy Commissioner to carry on the administration of the district. Till that time, the Garos were a head hunting tribe. In the records of the district, it is mentioned that from one village alone more than two hundred human skulls were recovered. It was the custom amongst the Garos to preserve the head of the man killed by them as a trophy. More the number of skulls gathered by an individual more honoured was his place in the society. It was considered as an act of valour and won respect and prestige from the members of the society. They not only carried on organised raids on the villages in the neighbouring districts, i.e., the villages in the districts of Mymensingh, now in East Pakistan, and Goalpara in Assam to collect the human heads but also carried on such raids on enemy villages within the districts of Garo Hills. I have mentioned in connection with the death ceremony that they used to consider it necessary to kill a human being on the occasion of the cremation of the dead body. For this purpose, they used to organise raids on the villages in the plains or on an enemy village in the hills to catch hold of a man who may be brought for the purpose of sacrifice, to be performed, near the funeral pyre. The Mimang (spirit of the dead) of this sacrificed man becomes a nokol, i.e., a servant of the Mimang of the dead person and accompanies the latter to the Mimang land at Balpakram. If a Mimang goes there without a nokol or a cow or some good presents, he is to live there as a nokol of the Mimangs who are well off there.’[303] ‘It was not until 1876 that the last trace of the head-hunting proclivities of the Garos disappeared. In the resolution on the annual report for that year I find it stated that the Deputy Commissioner was able while in camp at Rongrengiri, to settle a number of blood-feuds, and no less than 200 skulls, the remains of victims killed in former raids, or murdered in various ways, were surrendered and publicly burnt.’ [304] We have attempted to incorporate the head-hunting complex into this data sheet by making this association between head-hunting/human sacrifice and mortuary ritual explicit.

Largest scale collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Asongtata ceremony ♥ 'Asongtata ceremony. Close to the outskirts of every big village a number of stones may be noticed stuck into the ground, apparently without order or method. These are known by the name of asong, and on them is offered the sacrifice which the Asougtata demands. The sacrifice of a goat takes place, and a month later, that of a langur (Entellus monkey), or a bamboo-rat is considered necessary. The animal chosen has a rope fastened round its neck and is led by two men, one on each side of it, to every house in the village. It is taken inside each house in turn, the assembled villagers, meanwhile, beating the walls from the outside, to frighten and drive out any evil spirits which may have taken up their residence within. The round of the village having been made in this manner, the monkey or rat is led to the outskirts of the village, killed by a blow of a duo, which disembowels it, and then crucified on bamboos set up in the ground. Round the crucified animal long, sharp bamboo stakes are placed, which form chevaux de frise round about it. These commemorate the days when such defences surrounded the villages on all sides to keep off human enemies, and they are now a symbol to ward off sickness and dangers to life from the wild animals of the forest. The langur required for the purpose is hunted down some days before, but should it be found impossible to catch one, a brown monkey may take its place.' [305]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ yearly ♥ According to Ritual Database variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant', this ritual occurred 'annually' [306] [307].
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ yearly ♥ According to Ritual Database variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant', this ritual occurred 'annually' [308] [309].
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ not applicable ♥ According to Ritual Database variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant', this ritual occurred 'annually'. [310] [311]. Thomas Cressy: Due to the 'all or almost all' members of the community being participants, I have changed the code to 'not applicable'.
♠ Duration ♣ 9 ♥ hours. According to Ritual Database variable 'Ritual duration category', this ritual was '(3) = 6 to 12 hours/ extended'[312][313]. [314]
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 7,600 ♥ in absolute numbers. Ritual Database variable 'Members of other communities, tribal groups, towns' and participation from 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' are marked as 'present', meaning that size of the participating group is roughly equivalent to the size of the community. [315][316]. Given that the sacrificial animal is taken to every household, the participating group is quite large.
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ substantial minority ♥ It appears that any adult male could theoretically become a ritual specialist. 'Though the priest officiates at the sacrifice, it is the privilege of the nokma to provide for, or sanction it, and any attempt to usurp his rights quickly leads to litigation and a demand for compensation.'[317]
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ According to the Ritual Database [318], this ritual includes participation from 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' [319][320]
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ not applicable ♥ According to the Ritual Database [321], this ritual includes participation from 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' [322].[323] Thomas Cressy: Due to the 'all or almost all' members of the community being participants, I have changed the code to 'not applicable'.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Fasting' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [324][325]
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ absent ♥ 'Sleep deprivation' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database.[326][327]
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ 'Threats or actions that evince fear' and 'Dramatic acts evincing displays of emotion from participants (tears, laughter, rage, fear etc.)' are both coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database.[328][329]
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ 'Humiliation of participants' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database.[330][331]
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ 'Mention of disgust' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [332][333]
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [334][335]
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent' [336][337]. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database is 0, the lowest possible score.
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'.[338] [339]
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Practices that may result in excessive blood loss or deadly infection are all coded 'absent' on the Ritual Database.[340][341], including 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', 'Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula'.
♠ other ♣ ♥ List the other(s)
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ absent ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'.[342][343]
♠ alcohol ♣ absent ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Intake of alcohol' is coded as 'absent' [344][345]
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ absent ♥ 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [346][347]
♠ sex ♣ absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [348][349]
♠ dancing ♣ absent ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as 'absent'[350][351]

♠ entertainment ♣ inferred absent ♥ Not mentioned by source [354]

♠ currency ♣ absent ♥ no currency is recorded for this ritual.[360]
♠ property/valuable items ♣ present ♥ 'Other offering' is coded as 'present' in the Ritual Database.[361][362] Food offerings are made in a sacrificial manner.
♠ health costs ♣inferred absent ♥[363][364]
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ present ♥ 'The sacrifice of a goat takes place, and a month later, that of a langur (Entellus monkey), or a bamboo-rat is considered necessary.'[365]
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database.[366][367]
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database.[368][369]
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database.[370][371]
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most widespread collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Wangala ♥ 'After the rice harvest has been fully gathered in, the great sacrifice and festival of the year, the Wangala or Guréwata takes place. This is the most festive observance of the year, and combines religious sacrifice with much conviviality. The cost of the entertainment falls principally on the nokma of the village, who provides a pig to be eaten by his guests, and plenty of liquor. Among the Akawés and Chisaks of the north and north-eastern hills a curious feature of the ceremony is the manufacture of guré or “horses” out of pieces of plantain-stem for the body, and of bamboo for the head and legs. The image of the “horse” is laid on the floor of the nokma’s house, and the assembled guests dance and sing around it the whole night long, with the usual intervals for refreshments. Early the next morning, the “horse” is taken to the nearest river and launched on the water to find its way down stream on the current. For those who possess the necessary paraphernalia, the guré takes the shape of a horse’s head of large size, made of straw, and covered with cloth. The head is mounted on a stick, which a man holds before him in such a way that the head comes up to the level of his chest. Two straps pass over his shoulders to relieve his hands of the weight. The body of the “horse” is then built round his own body with cane and cloth. For a tail, yak’s tails are fastened in with his own hair, which, for the occasion, is allowed to hang down instead of being tied up. The performer commences to dance a shuffling step to the usual music. In front of him dances the priest, who goes through the pantomime of beckoning to the animal to come to him. The remaining guests of the nokma form a line of dancers behind the “horse”. When the first man gets tired, another takes his place, and the dancing goes on right through the night. A pleasant part of the performance is the pelting of the guré with eggs. Strictly speaking, this festival should last for three days and two nights. When it is over, the guré is taken to a stream and the body thrown into the water, the head being preserved for another year. The people who come to see it off, bring rice with them, and a meal by the water’s edge closes the proceedings. At the Wangala, it is the custom to mix flour with water, and for the assembled people to dip their hands into the mixture and make white hand-marks on the posts and walls of the house and on the backs of the guests.' [372]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ suspected unknown ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database [373], this ritual occurs 'annually'. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[374] Thomas Cressy: No evidence of the presence of ritual specialists is provided, so I have changed the code to 'suspected unknown'.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ yearly ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database,[375] this ritual occurs 'annually'. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[376]
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ not applicable ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database,[377] this ritual occurs 'annually'. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[378] Thomas Cressy: Due to the 'all or almost all' members of the community being participants, I have changed the code to 'not applicable'.
♠ Duration ♣ 46 ♥ hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual Database.[379], this ritual is coded as 'more than 12 hours'. 'Strictly speaking, this festival should last for three days and two nights.' [380]
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 125 ♥ in absolute numbers. According to the Ritual Database [381], 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' are 'present'. The Ritual Database states that a whole pig was given for this ritual. Estimating that a whole pig can feed approximately 125 people, I've estimated that the size of the participating group is 125. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[382]
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ suspected unknown ♥ It appears that any adult male could theoretically become a ritual specialist. According to the Ritual Database [383], 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' are 'present'. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[384] Thomas Cressy: No evidence of the presence of ritual specialists is provided, so I have changed the code to 'suspected unknown'.
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ According to the Ritual Database. [385] 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' are 'present'. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[386]
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ not applicable ♥ According to the Ritual Database [387], 'All or almost all members of community (>90%)' are 'present'. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[388] Thomas Cressy: Due to the 'all or almost all' members of the community being participants, I have changed the code to 'not applicable'.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'fasting' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'.[389] This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[390]
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Sleep deprivation' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'.[391] This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[392]
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Threats or actions that evince fear' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'.[393] This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[394]
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Humiliation of participants' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'.[395]. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[396]
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Mention of disgust' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'.[397] This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[398]
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database.[399] This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[400]
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing’, ‘Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'. [401] The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database is 1.67. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[402]
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'.[403] This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909)[404]
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Practices that could result in excessive blood loss or deadly infection are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database [405], including 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula'. Most frequent collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ Denbilsia ♥ 'The first of the annual cycle of village festivals was called Denbilsia and was observed after the completion of the clearing of the new swiddens, generally in January to February. Denbilsia was a one-day festival and was held at the nokma’s house. During the morning of the festival day, all the people gathered in front of the nokma’s house, where a bamboo altar was set up. Around noon, the nokma sacrificed a pig or a goat at this altar. After the sacrifice, the animal’s flesh was cut up and cooked, along with other foodstuffs, such as rice, fish, and other kinds of meat, and these were offered to all the villagers at a feast sponsored by the nokma. The nokma would also provide liberal amounts of rice-beer which the villagers drank all day long. After the feast, in the afternoon, the people would dance, sing and make music, activities which were continued until about midnight, when the villagers would return home to sleep.'[441]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ yearly ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Typical frequency of participation for patient (as patient)' and 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' are coded as 'annually' [442]. 'Denbilsia was a one-day festival and was held at the nokma’s house.' [443] The Ritual Database contains a 21 coded rituals for the A’chik, but none of these are more frequent than annual/yearly.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ yearly ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Typical frequency of participation for patient (as patient)' and 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' are coded as 'annually' [444]. 'Denbilsia was a one-day festival and was held at the nokma’s house.' [445] The Ritual Database contains a 21 coded rituals for the A’chik, but none of these are more frequent than annual/yearly.
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ not applicable ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Typical frequency of participation for patient (as patient)' and 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' are coded as 'annually' [446]. 'Denbilsia was a one-day festival and was held at the nokma’s house.' [447] The Ritual Database contains a 21 coded rituals for the A’chik, but none of these are more frequent than annual/yearly. Thomas Cressy: Due to the villagers being participants themselves for building the shrine and conducting the sacrifice, I have changed the code to 'not applicable' due to the community being active participants rather than passive spectators.
♠ Duration ♣ 17 ♥ hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual Database,[448] this ritual is coded as 'more than 12 hours'. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 141-145)[449]
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 5,600 ♥ in absolute numbers According to the Ritual Database,[450] 'Most members of community (50%-90%)' participate. Citing a community of size of roughly 8,000 people and estimating a .70 percent participation rate, I estimate that roughly 5,600 people are involved in this ritual. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 141-145)[451]
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ substantial minority ♥ It appears that any adult male could theoretically become a ritual specialist. According to the Ritual Database [452], the norma (village leader) appears to functions the ritual specialist. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 141-145)[453]
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ According to the Ritual Database [454], 'Most members of community (50%-90%)' participate. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 141-145)[455]
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ not applicable ♥ According to the Ritual Database [456], 'Most members of community (50%-90%)' participate. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 141-145)[457] Thomas Cressy: Due to the villagers being participants themselves for building the shrine and conducting the sacrifice, I have changed the code to 'not applicable' due to the community being active participants rather than passive spectators.

♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ (e.g. vomiting) 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database. [468] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 141-145)[469]
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing,’ Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent' [470]. The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database is 0. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 141-145)[471]
♠ mutilation ♣ absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'.[472] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 141-145)[473]
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Activities that may result in excessive blood loss or deadly infection are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database.[474] including 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula'. ♠ other ♣ absent ♥ List the other(s) No other costs are associated with this ritual.

Most euphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ post-funerary ceremony ♥ 'The post-funerary ceremony comprises a great feast, with dancing and singing, and lasts for two to three days. Sponsored by the dead person’s household, nobody has to receive a special invitation to attend the feast. The villagers are expected to come along, uninvited, and to join in the eating, singing and dancing. In the event of a really grand feast, villagers from other Garo communities will come along as well. The ceremony ends when all the food and drink prepared for the occasion has been consumed. In the evening of that final day, the delang is destroyed by fire and its ashes covered over with earth. I was told by some informants that one could determine what form of reincarnation the deceased’s soul would eventually take by observing the ground where the ashes of the delang had been covered with earth.'[511]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ suspected unknown ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database,[512] this ritual occurs 'less often than annually but usually more often than once in a lifetime'. This frequency must mean that this ceremony is not carried out after all deaths, which would occur on a yearly basis. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [513] Thomas Cressy: The evidence for ritual specialists was unclear, so I have changed it to 'suspected unknown'.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ once per generation ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database,[514] this ritual occurs 'less often than annually but usually more often than once in a lifetime'. This frequency must mean that this ceremony is not carried out after all deaths, which would occur on a yearly basis. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [515]
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ not applicable ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database,[516] this ritual occurs 'less often than annually but usually more often than once in a lifetime'. This frequency must mean that this ceremony is not carried out after all deaths, which would occur on a yearly basis. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [517] Thomas Cressy: As the people who attended the feast took part in the eatig, singing, and dancing, it seems there is no clear audience for this ritual. I have coded as 'not applicable'.
♠ Duration ♣ 60 ♥ hours. 'The post-funerary ceremony comprises a great feast, with dancing and singing, and lasts for two to three days.'[518]
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 180 ♥ in absolute numbers. Given that the A’chik community size if 100-199 (Ethnographic Atlas) and according to the Ritual Database, [519] 'Most members of the community (50%-90%)' participate as well as 'Members of other communities, tribal groups, towns', I estimate that roughly 180 individuals participate in this ritual. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [520]
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ suspected unknown ♥ There is no mention of a ritual specialist in Khaleque's account.[521] Thomas Cressy: The evidence in no way supports a 'whole polity' code, so I have changed it to 'suspected unknown'.
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ whole polity ♥ 'Sponsored by the dead person’s household, nobody has to receive a special invitation to attend the feast. The villagers are expected to come along, uninvited, and to join in the eating, singing and dancing. In the event of a really grand feast, villagers from other Garo communities will come along as well.' [522]
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ not applicable ♥ 'Sponsored by the dead person’s household, nobody has to receive a special invitation to attend the feast. The villagers are expected to come along, uninvited, and to join in the eating, singing and dancing. In the event of a really grand feast, villagers from other Garo communities will come along as well.' [523] Thomas Cressy: As the people who attended the feast took part in the eatig, singing, and dancing, it seems there is no clear audience for this ritual. I have coded as 'not applicable'.
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'fasting' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'. [524] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [525]
♠ vigil/sleep deprivation ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Sleep deprivation' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'.[526] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [527]
♠ fear ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Threats or actions that evince fear' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'.[528] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [529]
♠ humiliation ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Humiliation of participants' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'.[530] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [531]
♠ disgust ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'Mention of disgust' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'.[532] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [533]
♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database. [534] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [535]
♠ pain ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing’, ‘Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'. [536] The average peak dysphoria rating in the Ritual Database is 1.33. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [537]
♠ mutilation ♣ inferred absent ♥ 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'.[538] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [539]
♠ risk of death ♣ absent ♥ Activities that may result in excessive blood loss or deadly infection are coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database,[540] including 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing', Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula'. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [541]
♠ other ♣ ♥
Euphoric elements
♠ feasting ♣ present ♥ 'Some participants eat meal together' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'present'[542]. 'The post-funerary ceremony comprises a great feast, with dancing and singing, and lasts for two to three days.' [543]
♠ alcohol ♣ present ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Intake of alcohol' is coded as 'present'. [544] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [545]
♠ euphoria-inducing drugs (other than alcohol) ♣ absent ♥
♠ sex ♣ absent ♥ 'Sexual intercourse' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database. [546] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [547]
♠ dancing ♣ present ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as 'present'.[548] 'The post-funerary ceremony comprises a great feast, with dancing and singing, and lasts for two to three days.' [549]
♠ synchronous movement ♣ present ♥ (e.g. dancing or marching in unison) Ritual Database variable 'Dancing or repetitive rhythmic movement' is coded as 'present'. [550] Drumming also occurs. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [551]
♠ singing ♣ present ♥ Ritual Database variable 'Singing and (repetitive) rhythmic vocalization' is coded as 'present' [552]. 'The post-funerary ceremony comprises a great feast, with dancing and singing, and lasts for two to three days.' [553]
♠ entertainment ♣ present ♥ 'In the evening of that final day, the delang is destroyed by fire and its ashes covered over with earth.' [554]
♠ other ♣ ♥
Cohesion
♠ honour code ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ oath taking ♣ inferred absent ♥ There is no mention of a honour code or oath taking based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [555]
♠ enemies of any group member are my enemies ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ willingness to die for each other ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ obligations to each other's families ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ other ♣ ♥
♠ Orthopraxy checks ♣ inferred absent ♥ No obvious orthopraxy checks mentioned in Khaleque's account.[556]
♠ Orthodoxy checks ♣ absent ♥ Exegesis coded as 'largely transmitted before a ritual occurs, a participant asks or is told by another participant what the ritual does' in the Ritual Database.[557] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [558]
Costs of participation
♠ currency ♣ absent ♥ No formalised currency present. Not mentioned in Khaleque's account.[559]
♠ property/valuable items ♣ suspected unknown ♥
♠ health costs ♣ absent ♥ Not mentioned in Khaleque's account.[560]
♠ animal sacrifice ♣ present ♥ 'Sponsored by the dead person’s household, nobody has to receive a special invitation to attend the feast.' 'Sacrifice of animals' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database[561], but the ritual description mentions the killing of an animal. Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [562]
♠ human sacrifice of an out-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database.[563] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [564]
♠ human sacrifice of an in-group member ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database.[565] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [566]
♠ human sacrifice of a relative ♣ absent ♥ 'Sacrifice of humans' is coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database.[567] Based on data in (Khaleque 1988, 151) [568]
♠ other ♣ ♥

Most dysphoric collective ritual of the official cult[edit]

♠ Name ♣ traumatic birth ritual ♥ (Previous ritual no. 413 in Ritual Database) 'When a woman is about to be confined for the birthing, her husband vows to offer up a sacrifice of a bull, a goat, or a fowl, according to his means, if the child is safely born. The vow is fulfilled immediately after the birth, or, if the labour is of long duration, sometime after its commencement. The animal or bird is killed outside the house by the kamal, who recites a long incantation to avert the influence of evil spirits. The women who are attending the expectant mother have a like duty to perform. Rice is scattered on the floor of the house round their patient, and a chant kept up, of which the following is a translation: “Go away! go away! evil spirit; in the way of the n °ama, of the na °sa, of the banggni, and of the giljaré do not stand watching; do not prevent it; do not wait for it; do not watch; do not lick; do not swallow; do not smack your lips; do not let your mouth water.” The names above mentioned are those of fish, and they are intended as symbols for the child which is about to enter the world. (Beginning of ritual under consideration; ritual database ritual no. 414): Should the birth be long deferred, a goat is brought into the house, and its body placed in contact with that of the woman. At the same time the kamal takes a little water in his mouth, blows it in a fine spray over the woman, and utters the word “poinrang,” which seems to be nearly equivalent to “good luck.”' [569]
♠ Frequency for the ritual specialist ♣ yearly ♥ Given the relatively small community size of the A’chik and the infrequency of difficult births, this ritual may occur as often as once a year for the ritual specialist.
♠ Frequency per participant ♣ once per generation ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database,[570] this ritual occurs 'less often than annually but usually more often than once in a lifetime'. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909, 98-99).[571]
♠ Frequency for the audience ♣ once per generation ♥ According to variable 'Typical frequency of participation for average participant' in the Ritual Database,[572] this ritual occurs 'less often than annually but usually more often than once in a lifetime'. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909, 98-99).[573].
♠ Duration ♣ 0.5 ♥ Duration in hours. According to the 'Ritual duration category' of the Ritual Database,[574] this ritual is coded as 'short (1) = less than one hour'. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909, 98-99).[575].
♠ Typical size of participating group ♣ 10 ♥ in absolute numbers According to the Ritual Database,[576] 'Other small sub-group (<15)' participates in this ritual. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909, 98-99).[577]
♠ Inclusiveness (ritual specialist) ♣ midwives ♥ The kamal or specialist, which in this case is a midwife, can come from the whole polity [578]. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909, 98-99).[579].
♠ Inclusiveness (participants) ♣ suspected unknown ♥ Who to consider as a participant? We can't only include the mothers-to-be, as it has to be a collective ritual. Besides the mother, then, we may count the husband and attending women as well [580]. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909, 98-99).[581]
♠ Inclusiveness (audience) ♣ whole polity ♥ This ritual can be performed in the audience of males and females across the whole polity, whenever there is a difficult birth [582]. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909, 98-99).[583]
Dysphoric elements
♠ fasting ♣ absent ♥ The variable 'fasting' in the Ritual Database is coded as 'absent'.[584]. This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909, 98-99).[585].

♠ poisoning/dysphoria-causing drugs ♣ absent ♥ 'Vomiting', 'Intake of hallucinogenic drugs', and 'Intake of sedatives' are all coded as 'absent' in the Ritual Database. [594] This is based on a description in (Playfair 1909, 98-99).[595].
♠ pain ♣ absent ♥ 'Other uncomfortable experience', 'Burning of participants', 'Significant wound or bleeding', 'Superficial wound', 'Whipping/ beating of participants', 'Piercing’, ‘Scarification', 'Tattooing', 'Laceration of sensitive organs (skin, tongue, etc.)', and 'Circumcision/ removal of uvula' are all coded in the Ritual Database as 'absent'. ♠ other ♣ ♥

Phase II Variables (polity-based)[edit]

Institutional Variables[edit]

♠ RA ♣ Eva Brandl ♥

♠ Expert ♣ ♥

♠ Editor ♣ ♥

Note: Prior to colonization, the A’chik were not governed by a state structure. Clans and lineages exercised social control on the village and local levels: ‘In Garo society the most important social group is the clan known as MACHONG. A machong is an exogamous matrilineal descent group wherein a Garo is automatically assigned by birth to the unilineal group of his mother. A CHATCHI (moiety) is divided into many machong. Each married couple chooses one daughter--or, if they have none, they adopt a close relative of the mother--to be heiress (NAKNA DONQIPIKA MECHIK) of the family. Her husband traditionally is selected from the lineage group of the father and is accepted as the NOKROM of the house. He resides with his wife in her parents' house. He has to take on the responsibility of looking after his parents-in-law during their old age, and his wife inherits the property.’ [636] Local authority was exercised by lineage elders: ‘The authority within a lineage is exercised according to age, the older member always being allowed to direct and punish the younger members. The age differences are otherwise symbolized in only one way-the order in which rice beer is served. When beer is first passed out at a gathering, the people should be served in order of formal seniority. A maternal uncle should be served before his nephew, and an older brother before a younger one. Even an older sister may precede a younger brother, though generally men and women do not drink together. [...] In spite of this formal deference, older people do not monopolize positions of power, and an old person cannot exercise authority outside his lineage simply because of his age. One defers to one’s lineage seniors, but not to old people in general.’ [637] Village headmen acted as intermediaries in local disputes: ‘Among the Garos most disputes arise over the issues of property, inheritance, and domestic quarrels within the family. Such problems are to a large extent settled by the MAHARI (lineage) of the offended and the offender. A new situation develops when someone's cattle cause damage to another's crops. Under such situation the NOKMA (village headman) acts as an intermediary only. If he fails to settle the dispute, the matter can go to the civil court of the district council.’ [638] ‘Traditionally, the nokma’s position was connected with the indigeneous customary rites. His temporal and ritual powers in a traditional society were linked with his position. The conversion of a nokma to Christianity automatically led to the loss of his ritualistic role. When the nokma’s were endowed with real temporal power, the resistance was great as Nokmas were non-Christians. But when the Nokma accepted Christianity, nokmaship passed to another person who could act as a nokma in performing rites and rituals. However, the Government still recognized the converted persons as nokmas. This created dislocation in the traditional system, one looking after the customary right and other ritual responsibilities. As the author has tried to show that in the traditional system the two roles cannot be separated, the two roles are enmeshed into each other.’ [639] Nokmas also formally held titles to land: ‘In a Garo village very little difference of status is seen. A particular clan holds right of ownership of the village homestead and shifting cultivation lands, and the title of ownership is inherited by a particular household. The head of the land-owning household is known as the nokma, and the particular area under which he holds ownership right is known as a’king. He also acts as the religious head of the village, and he is to perform the ceremonies for the general well-being of the village. He is called upon to settle disputes between villagers. But in all his decisions he is guided by the elders of the village. He is not entitled to any tribute from the villagers, and he has no special paraphernalia to indicate himself as the nokma. However, in the village a rich man gets respect, because in times of need people have to seek help from him. But in a Garo village it is usually very rare to find an extremely rich man. To a Garo wealth consists of a number of brass gongs called rang and some ornaments made of silver or some such metal. Now-a-days a gun is also regarded as the status symbol of a wealthy man.’ [640] Formalization was largely absent from village councils and trials: ‘The Rules require the village court to “try all suits and cases in accordance with the customary laws of the village.” Village courts are supposed to be non-professional bodies and decide [minor, village-level] cases in an informal atmosphere without procedural technicalities and formalities.’ [641] During colonial rule, supralocal executive offices were superimposed onto village- and lineage-based A’chik structures: ‘When the Britishers took over the administration of this district, one witnessed an imposition of hierarchy of new political and administrative units in the district over the traditional democratic village set-up. The British Government, being actuated with the desire to have effective control over the villages and to facilitate the collection of revenues and house tax introduced the office of laskar with limited police, civil and criminal powers. Accordingly there was a laskar over a circle of villages; each having jurisdiction covering ten or twelve of villages. Although, the villagers were left to settle all disputes through the nokma and the village courts, they had right to appeal to the court of laskars against the decisions of the village councils.’ [642] ’In the same way the introduction of offices of sardar, hill mandal and hill mauzadar curtailed the powers and authorities of the nokmas and their village councils. The new offices were created for the effective administration over the Garo with the idea of village self-government under the direct control of Deputy Commissioner at the centre.’ [643] Village headmen and elders were not bureaucrats, but mediated between village self-governance and colonial authorities: ‘Many of the disputes of the Garos were decided in their village Panchayats. When a man has some complaints against another he reports them to the Nokma or the village-head. If the nature of the complaints is simple, the Nokma in a meeting of the few leading persons of the village, decides the dispute; but if the nature of the complaints is complicated and not easy of solution the Nokma reports the matter to the Laskar. The Laskar is a very important and influential man in the Garo Hills District. The hills areas are divided into some elekas and each of such elekas is placed under a Laskar for convenient collection of the house tax as well as for deciding the disputes of small nature locally. The Laskar need not essentially be a literate man, worldly prudence is enough for the management of his eleka. In practice a Laskar wields immense influence in his eleka.’ [644] The degree of professionalization differs according to administrative level, with full-time bureaucrats restricted to the higher ones. Judges employed at government courts and other top officials functioned on a higher administrative level than the native village councils and were solely dependent on the colonial or independent Indian district executive: ‘During the first few years of the British rule in Assam the district of Garo Hills was treated as a part of the Goalpara district. The whole tract was placed under a Civil Commissioner. This officer took into his hands the collection of rents claimed by the Zaminders from the Garos, and abolished the duties levied by them on the hill producers. For some years a policy of non-interference was followed but without the desired success; so it was decided to appoint an officer-in-charge of the hills and in 1869 a.d. the Garo Hills were formed into a separate district with Tura as its headquarters. It is said in some parts of the district even now that the British administrators had to get away with many of the influential chiefs and other men of the tribe by killing them for, they could not easily bow down to the foreigners. Once this hills area was completely brouht undegr the control of the government, the Garos lived peacefully.’ [645] ‘The judicial officers (who preside over those courts) are appointed by, or with the approval of the Governor. The rules as to administration of justice do not contain specific provisions as to their tenure and salary, or as to their full time or part time character. But most of these matters will be regulated as rules or orders issued under Rule 15 of the Assam Autonomous Districts (Constitution of District Councils) Rules, 1951. It may be of interest to note that there is a specific prohibition against a member of the Executive Committee being appointed to these courts. To this extent, their independence is protected. A legal practitioner can appear before these courts. But in cases where an accused is not arrested, the legal practitioner takes the permission of the District Council Court for such appearance.’ [646] Positions given to native petty officials were less formalized: ‘The loskor has several duties. He collects the house tax within his district, keeping a fixed portion of this as his own payment, and he organizes work parties to keep the roads open. His most important duty, however, is to supervise and try to settle legal disputes. The loskor sometimes appoints one or more assistants called sordars, to whom the District Council pays an annual stipend of 100 Rupees, together with a shirt and a pair of short pants. Saljing, who lived in Rengsanggri, was a sordar; but not every village had one, and a sordar does not have jurisdiction over a particular village. As a general assistant to the loskor he may assist in collecting information about a dispute, and in petty matters a sordar may sit as representative of the loskor and preside at a trial. The loskorship demands a large part of a man’s time, but a sordar spends most of his time working in his fields like his neighbors.’ [647] The material seems to indicate that native officials performed their duties on a part-time basis only. Appointed officials on the lower, less professionalized level received stipends or drew their wages from tax income. Lineage elders were appointed to colonial courts on a temporary basis, but only as advisers: ‘The District Council may, whenever it deems necessary, also nominate two or more local elders well conversant with the tribal usages and customary laws, to sit with the judicial officer of the court as a bench and may, by order, invest such bench with any of the powers conferred or conferrable by or under the rules for the trial of suits and cases based on the tribal usages and the tribal customary laws only.’ [648] While village headmen were acknowledged by the British administration, the imposition of appointed officials led to a loss of political power among Nokmas: ’In the same way the introduction of offices of sardar, hill mandal and hill mauzadar curtailed the powers and authorities of the nokmas and their village councils. The new offices were created for the effective administration over the Garo with the idea of village self-government under the direct control of Deputy Commissioner at the centre.’ [649] ‘There was a move for retention of the old institution of nokmaship which could not function with authority since the British administration had appointed the laskars and sardars for the smooth running of their administration from 1824 onwards. The nokmas became only the clan chief and custodian of the clan land a’king. The nokma could not administer effectively as he used to do prior to the British administration in the district. The nokmas were supposed to be well versed with their functions and duties in the villages. The British administration enforced the Rules of Administration of Justice in the Garo Hills both Civil and Police in 1937. These rules have been renewed again and again. They are in use till the present day. The head of the district administration was the Deputy Commissioner and his Assistants and it has never been changed.’ [650] The result was a complex system made up of colonial administrators, native headmen, and petty officials who mediated between formal and informal forms of authority. Accordingly, some of the below variables may not be applicable to the colonial period. It may be expedient to code for the British governors rather than Nokmas in this case.

Limits on Power of the Chief Executive[edit]

Legal (formal) limits[edit]

♠ Executive power is separate or independent from military ♣ absent ♥ Given the absence of a standing A’chik army, the village headmanship should be taken as the primary institution for ad-hoc, improvised military organization. Male villagers probably acted as war parties under the leadership of a nokma: ‘In the early days, the Garos used to wage many wars. Such an occasion arose once (perhaps the first of such warfare) when people of one village living under a certain Nokma went to work for their hadang (field for cultivation) beyond their area and entered another Nokma’s jurisdiction. This was a cause of conflict, and they started fighting. There were heavy casualties on both sides. Finally, both the parties ran away to their own area. Thus neither party gained or lost any land.’ [651] We are unsure whether village headmen got involved with the colonial military. We have replicated the code from the colonial-era data sheet for the time being, but this is open to review. Given the institutional transformations of the colonial period, this variable may not be applicable, though.
♠ Executive power is separate or independent from legislative ♣ absent ♥ Local disputes were settled in informal village councils: ‘Among the Garos most disputes arise over the issues of property, inheritance, and domestic quarrels within the family. Such problems are to a large extent settled by the MAHARI (lineage) of the offended and the offender. A new situation develops when someone's cattle cause damage to another's crops. Under such situation the NOKMA (village headman) acts as an intermediary only. If he fails to settle the dispute, the matter can go to the civil court of the district council.’ [652] ‘The Rules require the village court to “try all suits and cases in accordance with the customary laws of the village.” Village courts are supposed to be non-professional bodies and decide [minor, village-level] cases in an informal atmosphere without procedural technicalities and formalities.’ [653] These were made up of influential wealthy men: 'People admire the rich men, but they do not defer to them in any formal manner, and an observer could not possibly tell from watching a group of men in ordinary daily pursuits which of them were rich and which poor. If one looked at the size of their houses or measured the size of their fields, however, the relative position of the men would become fairly clear, and the more one observed the details of personal relations, the clearer it would become. Village life is so organized that few important village-wide decisions must be made, but when problems do arise people are usually willing to go along with the decisions of [Page 208] the elite. The nokma must formally designate the day for ceremonies, but before doing so he informally samples the opinions of other wealthy men. If disagreements arise about the distribution of plots for cultivation, the wealthy men can usually carry along public opinion toward some solution. I once watched villagers buying a cow for a ceremony. Every household had contributed money toward the price of the cow, but it was four or five wealthy men who put their heads together and decided whether or not to try to make the seller come down in price. These are not profound questions; but somebody must decide them, and most villagers are happy to leave them to the wealthy men. After all, they “feed” the poorer people, and their very wealth is evidence of their ability. My own judgment of the ability of the various men in the village was close to the consensus of the villagers. I agreed with them that the wealthy people were often more able and intelligent than the others. It does take more than ordinary ability to accumulate or hold on to wealth.'
